current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text:
To develop a model disclosure form to assist consumers in
		  purchasing long-term care insurance.

sponsor.#tail:
introduced
			 the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the

committee-name.#text:
Committee on Health, Education, Labor,
			 and Pensions

			 Right-to-Know Act of 2013

text.#text:
The
			 term

header.#text:
NAIC study and
			 report on State disclosure requirements for long-term care insurance

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall request the NAIC to carry out the
			 activities described in
and issue the report described in
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Long-Term Care Insurance Consumer Right-to-Know Act of 2013/s:3/ss:b
Long-Term Care Insurance Consumer Right-to-Know Act of 2013/s:3/ss:c

text.#text: The

The
			 activities described in this subsection are the following:

header.#text:
Review and
			 development of proposed model disclosure requirements

text.#text:
Review and describe disclosure
			 requirements for long-term care insurance policies under the Model Act and
			 regulation.

header.#text:
Model act and
			 regulation disclosure requirements

text.#text:
Review and describe disclosure
			 requirements for long-term care insurance policies under State laws.

Review and describe differences in long-term care
			 services, including with respect to providers of such services and the settings
			 in which such services are provided among States and develop a standardized
			 definition for long-term care services.

Identify and describe key issues to consider in the
			 development of a proposed model form for marketing long-term care insurance
			 policies.

header.#text:
Identification
			 of key issues for development of model disclosure marketing
			 form

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
and the descriptions
			 required under that subsection.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Long-Term Care Insurance Consumer Right-to-Know Act of 2013/s:3/ss:a

text.#text:
The
			 report described in this subsection is a NAIC White Paper that is issued not
			 later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act and contains the
			 results of the reviews conducted under

header.#text:
NAIC Working
			 Group to develop model disclosure form for long-term care insurance

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall request the NAIC to establish, not
			 later than 60 days after the date on which the NAIC White Paper described in
is issued and in consultation with the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Long-Term Care Insurance Consumer Right-to-Know Act of 2013/s:3/ss:c

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: and the

, a Working Group to develop a model disclosure form for
			 marketing long-term care insurance policies.

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall
			 be composed of the following:
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Long-Term Care Insurance Consumer Right-to-Know Act of 2013/s:4/ss:a

text.#text: The Working Group established under

Representatives
			 from State Departments of Health (or the most appropriate State agencies with
			 responsibility for oversight of the provision of long-term care).

Representatives
			 of long-term care providers and facilities.

Consumer
			 advocates.

Representatives
			 of issuers of long-term care insurance policies.

Representatives
			 of the NAIC or State insurance commissioners.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: and
or the NAIC.

text.#text:
Other experts in
			 long-term care and long-term care insurance policies selected by the

In
			 developing the model form, the Working Group shall consider the
			 following:

Variations among
			 providers, services, and facilities in the long-term care and long-term care
			 insurance markets.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Long-Term Care Insurance Consumer Right-to-Know Act of 2013/s:3/ss:c

text.#text:
The results of
			 the reviews and the descriptions included in the NAIC White Paper issued under

Such other
			 information and factors as the Working Group determines appropriate.

The
			 Working Group shall ensure that the model has—

minimum standard
			 language for use by issuers of such policies, and for agents selling such
			 policies, in explaining the services and benefits covered under the policies
			 and restrictions on the services and benefits;

minimum standard
			 format, color, and type size for disclosure documents; and

such other
			 minimum standards as the Working Group determines appropriate.

The Working Group shall issue a proposed model
			 disclosure form for marketing long-term care insurance policies not later than
			 1 year after the date on which the Working Group is established.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall
			 request the NAIC to amend the Model Act and regulation to require the use of
			 the proposed model disclosure form issued by the Working Group, not later than
			 1 year after the date on which the Working Group issues the form.

header.#text:
Adoption and

Required use of
			 model disclosure form in marketing long-term care insurance policies

shall promulgate a regulation

			 final, any issuer of a qualified long-term care insurance contract that covers

of
			 such section to use the proposed model disclosure form for marketing such

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
or a long-term care insurance policy
			 offered in connection with a State plan amendment described in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
clause (iii) of section 1917(b)(1)(C) of the Social

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Long-Term Care Insurance Consumer Right-to-Know Act of 2013/s:4

Not later than 18
